Butler Community College
Purdue University


PROJECT DESCRIPTION
The project is exploring the design and manufacturing of guitars to better engage students that otherwise may not be connected to STEM oriented subject matter. It uses the context of building a guitar to explore difficult theoretical concepts (e.g., relationship of the time/frequency domains) and advance STEM learning by: 1) quantifying the student learning gains that result from the implementation of the new STEM guitar curriculum, 2) improving and expanding a variety of faculty professional development activities, and 3) focusing additional curriculum development activities to incorporate national standards and address gaps in skills that are identified by industry participants. Comprehensive ten-day faculty professional development institutes are being conducted to engage faculty teams in the discovery of new STEM learning tools/techniques and build a diverse community of regional partners.


BROADER SIGNIFICANCE
More than 19,000 students are being impacted during the course of the three-year effort, as a result of faculty members adopting or adapting the curriculum developed through the project. Working with their peers and professional development institute facilitators, educators are studying the STEM principles associated with building guitars and developing applied STEM learning activities that are aligned with core curriculum national standards. Faculty are being recruited from underserved populations and are preparing a website to enable high school students to experiment with the physics, mathematics, and engineering design/manufacturing concepts that are associated with the project. The project's website offers educators widespread access to an exciting STEM learning community, allowing them to keep in contact with other professionals who are engaged in the curriculum implementation and professional development activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National STEM Guitar Project

Many students today have never learned how to make things. Unfortunately, we have removed this style of learning from schools around the country.

Our project fully integrates applied learning techniques combined with traditional STEM subject matter. It is being used from middle school through university level courses and cuts across many social, economic, and diversity barriers. The hard and soft skills that are learned in the program apply directly to technician skills used in industry including: team work, quality, tool usage (power and hand), self-confidence, problem solving, and traditional theory of STEM topics.

The STEM Guitar Project hosted eighteen fully funded Guitar Building Institutes annually since 2010, through which over 19,000 students have been reached nationally through 287 trained faculty. Over the life of the project, over 600 trained faculty have taken the training with the program. During the projects tenure we have reached to 47 US states, 2 providences in Canada, a school program in Australia, and the University of Median in Columbia. (Foreign implementation locations did not receive any NSF funding or support).

The project features hands-on applied learning of innovative guitar building techniques, resulting in life-changing experiences for middle, high school and post-secondary students and educators, thus sparking excitement for learning STEM subject matter and pursuing STEM careers. The project hosts Guitar Building Institutes around the United States annually since 2008, impacting nearly 6,000 students nationally each year around the US. The 5-day educator/student institute combines instructional activities and training on science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) with hands-on applied learning guitar building techniques

The project has also started a guitar kit manufacturing program managed at Sinclair Community College. Central Washington State University is also participating in the manufacturing support of the STEM guitar project.  Guitar kits are manufactured and sold to educational institutions to support the tactile learning that is taking place in the classroom.  The project continues to expand this entrepreneurial opportunity to other schools to participate so they can also generate income to help offset costs and provide a unique learning opportunity for students. These guitar kits have been reviewed and approved by our industry advisory team, which includes master builders and luthiers from the guitar manufacturing industry. 

This project continues to grow organically, we have received orders for guitar kits from faculty and schools that have not participated in the summer institute program and are using our curriculum and video learning tools to implement the program locally.  This was an unexpected result of our project. 

Our goal is to help engage students through the opportunity to weave curriculum and hands on learning. With the growth we have seen over the last 4 years, we are making an impact across the United States. 

To learn more about the project visit www.guitarbuilding.org or the STEM guitar Facebook page
